Waypoints.Name: Gross Kidney Anatomy
Waypoints.Description:
The role of the kidney is to filter blood and concentrate waste into urine. Nephrons are the functional unit of the kidney. Within the nephron, blood is filtered in the glomeruli, and waste products are concentrated and transported via the proximal and distal tubules, loop of Henle and collecting ducts. The nephron extends across the two major zones of the kidney: the cortex and the medulla. Glomeruli are located in the cortex and the tubule systems extend from the cortex into the medulla.

The Kidney is a 5 Âµm FFPE tissue section from a 41-year-old man.

The sample was visualized with PanCK (epithelial cells), CD10+CD31 (proximal convoluted tubules and endothelial cells), and SYTO 83 (nuclei). In parallel, the sample was molecularly profiled with the [**GeoMx Human Whole Transcriptome Atlas (WTA) assay**](https://www.nanostring.com/products/geomx-digital-spatial-profiler/geomx-rna-assays/geomx-whole-transcriptome-atlas/).

You can click on the cortex and medulla in the cartoon to see them outlined on the tissue image, and you can toggle the Regions of Interest (ROIs) that were molecularly profiled by clicking All Structures as a data layer.

Waypoints.Name: Detailed Kidney Anatomy
Waypoints.Description:
With GeoMx DSP, Regions of Interest (ROIs) are selected by the user and then molecularly profiled. These ROIs can be either profiled whole (i.e. geometric profiling) or subdivided based on the visible morphology markers into compartments and profiled separately (i.e. segmented profiling).

In the cartoon below, the key features of the nephron are highlighted and corresponding ROIs are mapped on the tissue image to the right.
1. Cortical Glomerulus: Geometric 
2. Cortical Filtration Membrane: CD10/CD31+ Segmented
3. Juxtamedullary Glomerulus: Geometric 
4. Juxtamedullary Filtration Membrane: CD10/CD31+ Segmented
5. Proximal Convoluted Tubule: Geometric 
6. Distal Convoluted Tubule: PanCK+ Segmented
7. Loop of Henle: PanCK+ Segmented
8. Collecting Duct: PanCK+ Segmented

Waypoints.Name: Linking Molecular and Imaging Data
Waypoints.Description: One of the key aspects of spatial biology is the ability to link molecular and spatial (image) data. In this figure, the average number of genes detected per ROI by structure is shown. Select the box plot to see the ROIs for that structure.

Waypoints.Name: Distribution of Cells
Waypoints.Description:
Here, we are measuring the relative abundance of different cell types within each ROI using a [**cell deconvolution algorithm**](https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.08.04.235168).
In this graph, each row is a single ROI, and each structure has a unique composition of cell types. For example, proximal convoluted tubules are enriched for epithelial cells of the proximal tubule, whereas distal convoluted tubules are enriched for intercalated cell (Type A). The cell deconvolution matrix comes from the [**Human Cell Atlas**](https://data.humancellatlas.org/explore/projects/abe1a013-af7a-45ed-8c26-f3793c24a1f4).

Waypoints.Name: Spatial Mapping of Gene Pathways
Waypoints.Description: Whole transcriptome profiling allows us to spatially map functional gene pathways and gene sets, as well as individual genes. This heatmap of single sample gene set enrichment (ssGSEA) shows relative expression of transporter gene sets in different ROIs. For clarity, only a few structure types are shown. For example, ABC transporters (top row) are enriched in proximal convoluted tubules, whereas SLC39 metal ion transporters (bottom row) are enriched in collecting ducts.

Waypoints.Name: Differential Gene Expression
Waypoints.Description: Spatially resolving whole transcriptome data allows us to generate new hypotheses about the tissue biology. Based on biochemical profiling, we know that cortical nephrons have primarily excretory and regulatory functions, while juxtamedullary nephrons concentrate and dilute urine. This volcano plot of the differential gene expression between cortical and juxtamedullary glomeruli allows us to see the different genes expressed in the two ROI types that underlie their different functional roles.

Waypoints.Name: Validating Gene Expression with Protein Expression
Waypoints.Description:
We explored the relationship between our data and the [**Human Proteome Atlas**](www.proteinatlas.org) to see if the gene expression patterns we observed would also be detected at the protein level. As seen in the immunohistochemistry image below, NPHS2 is a protein marker for glomeruli. 

![image](img/NPHS2_IHC.png)

[*Image credit: Human Protein Atlas.*](https://www.proteinatlas.org/ENSG00000116218-NPHS2#gene_information)

NPHS2 transcript was only observed in the glomerulus and filtration membrane ROIs, demonstrating that the gene expression levels concur the protein distributions. This is independent and orthogonal validation of the expression patterns for these targets.

Waypoints.Name: Segregation by Histological Substructure
Waypoints.Description: Dimensionality reduction enables a high-level exploration of the similarities and differences between ROIs. For example, collecting duct and loop of Henle ROIs cluster tightly, while proximal and distal convoluted tubule clusters are very dispersed. Glomeruli and filtration membranes are tightly clustered, with modest separation between cortical and juxtamedullary ROIs.
